The Stade de France crowd, which had jeered goalkeeper Fabien Barthez and Domenech before the game, booed the home team at the final whistle.

But there was a glimmer of hope for Heerenveen with eleven minutes remaining as Shola Ameobi briefly turned defender in his own area, challenging substitute Marcel Seip in the air and only succeeding in handling the ball.

Parma were given the opportunity to take the lead after 25 minutes when they were awarded a penalty after Daniele Degano was upended by Fatih Sonkaya inside the box following a counterattacking move, but Gilardino's weak spot-kick was saved by Ramazan low to his right.

The tension in Tbilisi was lifted slightly with ten minutes to play when Albania defender Elvin Bequiri upended Levan Tskitishvili and earned a red card.

Raúl, sandwiched between Panucci and Dellas, was judged to have been pushed while leaping for a cross.
The game then opened up and PSV missed a golden chance to get back into the match in the 63rd minute when Van Bommel's penalty was saved by Galinovic after the goalkeeper had brought down Park.

Mesika was denied by the feet of Vilnrotter, Ishmael Addo headed over and the HJK custodian also dived bravely to prevent a Liran Cohen shot.
On 51 minutes Zenden picked up Queudrue’s pass on the left and sprinted forward, cutting inside before shooting inside the near post from the edge of the box.

After García had had claims for a penalty against Alessandro Nesta waved away, Milan surged upfield, Kaká found Shevchenko sprinting through the inside-right channel and there was Crespo to tuck away his strike partner's astute square pass.

A last-minute penalty from Stefan Blank earned TSV Alemannia Aachen a 2-2 draw against FC Zenit St. Peterburg in Cologne and ensured that the German side retained their hopes of progressing from UEFA Cup Group H while denying the Russian visitors the opportunity to seal their place in the last 32.

A late goal from Mickaël Isabey helped FC Sochaux-Montbéliard clinch second place in Group D as opponents Panionios NFC were eliminated from the competition.
AJ Auxerre progressed to the inaugural UEFA Cup group stage following a comfortable defeat of Danish side Aalborg BK at the Abbé-Deschamps stadium in this first round, second-leg tie.
Meanwhile, Auxerre have advanced to the last eight after overcoming AFC Ajax and fellow Ligue 1 contenders LOSC Lille Métropole.

Turkey's Gençlerbirligi eliminated Blackburn Rovers FC, Sporting Clube de Portugal and Parma FC in reaching the fourth round last season before losing to eventual winners Valencia CF, but their visitors claimed a crucial away goal through Georgios Barkoglou, and the home side were unable to score the three they needed to turn the tie - Egaleo's maiden outing in the UEFA Cup.

The Armenian champions had eliminated FK Pobeda in the previous round, but fell behind to Mircea Lucescu's side on 31 minutes when 19-year-old Romanian striker Ciprian Marica scored his first European goal for Shakhtar.

A 1-1 draw a fortnight ago had set up a tight second leg, but although Shakhtyor would have progressed with a goalless result, coach Yuri Verheichyk sent out an attacking formation combining Anatoli Tsikhanchyk and Igors Slesarcuks.

After the first leg finished 2-1, Kazbek Tuaev's team needed to win and took the early initiative with midfield players Mahmud Gurbanov and veteran Vidadi Rzayev dictating the play.

Their Group D encounter in England's north-east, where Sporting would return in the Round of 16 to defeat Middlesbrough FC, finished 1-1 - although both sides were already realistically assured of their places in the knockout stage before kick-off.
Ronaldo, who had switched to the left flank, after being well marked by Eric Abidal, crossed from the by-line and the Dutch international angled a deft header inside Grégory Coupet's far post.

Despite seeing plenty of the ball, the French team were finding it hard to create any threat as the half-hour passed, with strikers Javier Saviola and Emmanuel Adebayor well shackled by the PSV defence.
None the less, Georgia started the second half brightly, but forwards Shota Arveladze and Sandro Iashvili were well shackled by the home defence.

A cramped midfield of Carsten Ramelow, Bernd Schneider and Marko Babic – preferred to striker Andrej Voronin – kept Roma captain Francesco Totti shackled and the echoes around the empty stadium appeared to subdue the mood of both sides.
In the 48th minute, Saviola threaded a pass through for Chevantón but the Uruguayan was brilliantly marshalled by Wilfred Bouma who eventually blocked the shot.
With the fit-again Adriano marshalled by Jaap Stam, Inter failed to get the early goal they wanted and their task became even more daunting on 30 minutes when Milan opened the scoring.
Vieira, however, was closely marked by the Israeli midfield, restricting his influence.
First Markus Kiesenebner flashed a header past the upright on 55 minutes, before Tosin Dosunmu was denied by Ignacio Lafuente on a one-on-one.
As Vilnrotter hesitated, Larmour nipped in and robbed him.
On 16 minutes Hungary went close when Robert Waltner was dispossessed by Maltese goalkeeper Justin Haber at the last gasp.
The Wales international scampered free down the right flank only to be denied by Ricardo, who rushed off his line to close down the striker.
Jamie Pace won the ball on the touchline, and found Etienne Barbara well placed in the Primorje penalty box, but his shot was well wide.
Seven minutes after the restart, HJK went close again when Reoven Oved was robbed in midfield, and the visitors broke.
Tuncay, in particular, was finding space and had already seen one shot saved by Grégory Coupet when he was sent clear on the right, only to be denied by Eric Abidal's strong tackle.

Four minutes later Maccarone went close with a right-footed shot that Tudor deflected wide for a corner, then Steaua captain Mirel Radoi denied compatriot Ianis Zicu with a superb sliding tackle after Alessandro Rosina's low cross.

The tension in Tbilisi was lifted slightly with ten minutes to play when Albania defender Elvin Bequiri upended Levan Tskitishvili and earned a red card.

Brugge coach Trond Sollied knew his side would have to match Austria's performance in the Netherlands to progress, but his pre-match plans suffered a setback when Croatian striker Boško Balaban was ruled out with a knee injury he sustained in last weekend's Belgian First Division meeting with RSC Anderlecht.

Schalke coach Ralf Rangnick was without midfield player Jörg Böhme and defender Fabian Lamotte, while defender Murat Yakin missed out for Basel.
Liverpool manager Rafael Benítez played Stephen Warnock in place of Harry Kewell, who has just recovered from a thigh strain, while Dietmar Hamann deputised for the injured Steven Gerrard.
Crespo was in the side as he continues to deputise for the injured Andriy Shevchenko, and played at the apex of a three-pronged attack with Rui Costa and Kaká.
Sporting coach José Peseiro kept centre-back Beto and winger Rodrigo Tello on the bench, while Anderson Polga and Custódio missed out altogether.

PSV's good work was almost undone in the 13th minute when Edwin Zoetebier, deputising for the injured Heurelho Gomes in goal, slipped in clearing a simple back-pass, presenting the ball to Frode Johnsen.

Slovakia next face Latvia in Bratislava on 9 October while Liechtenstein, who lost their opening qualifier 2-1 at home to Estonia in August, are at home to UEFA EURO 2004™ finalists Portugal the same day.

Having lost at home against Norway on Saturday, Scotland were keen to bounce back and early on Stevie Crawford came close as he went past Serghei Lascencov and sent in a shot that went just over the crossbar.

It was a fitting climax to a game that swung one way then the other, with the hosts trailing 1-0, leading 2-1, and falling behind 18 minutes from the end when Austria captain Markus Schopp claimed his second goal of the game.

Nine minutes after the restart Geraerts picked up a loose ball and shot beyond Berti to set up a tense and hotly contested final half-hour during which both teams created chances.
After receiving the ball from Alessandro Del Piero in the box, and finding his way blocked, Mauro Camoranesi flicked it to Nedved who stabbed the ball into the top left-hand corner.

The equaliser shocked Besiktas but they composed themselves as Emre Asik got his head to a long punt and Carew toe-poked in for the second.
But as in CSKA's 1-0 defeat by Chelsea on Matchday 4, the spot-kick was wasted, Ignashevich this time blasting over the bar.

If anything, the Albanians appeared to be keener to break the deadlock - and they got their reward on the hour when Bushaj raced after a bouncing ball, outstripped two defenders for pace and neatly nodded the ball into the net.
Daniele Bonera sent a long clearance upfield which Alberto Gilardino delightfully back-heeled into the path of Marco Marchionni.
A minute before the interval, Dejan Stankovic doubled the lead, the FC Internazionale Milano man lobbing Gasperoni from 27 metres out after collecting a pass from Ivica Dragutinovic.
After 35 minutes Trezeguet took advantage of careless defending by Toni Kuivasto and the Frenchman made no mistake as he blasted the ball in from mid-range.

First Omonia's Kekic saw his effort cleared off the line by Evgeni Iordanov, then Mujiri broke the offside trap only to shoot wide for CSKA before Kekic volleyed wide at the other end, all in the 52nd minute.
The goalkeeper appeared to have control of the ball, but Boya raced in to kick it over the line, provoking a furious response from the Lazio players.
Mista's rustiness was cruelly exposed when an Aimar shot deflected beyond Bremen goalkeeper Andreas Reinke to the back post but with a free chance to score the striker nodded wide.
Dynamo responded with Diogo Rincón curling the ball just over on ten minutes but most of their approaches were foiled by Madrid's central defensive pair of Iván Helguera and Francisco Pavón.

It was a fitting climax to a game that swung one way then the other, with the hosts trailing 1-0, leading 2-1, and falling behind 18 minutes from the end when Austria captain Markus Schopp claimed his second goal of the game.

Three minutes from time, with the rain by now coming down heavily, the hero of the night, Archavin, was brought off to a tremendous reception from the home crowd, the smile on his face a stark contrast to the bewildered look worn by Crvena Zvezda's players.

Bursts of driving hailstones were making conditions difficult for both sides, and McClaren opted to make a double defensive substitution at half-time, withdrawing Morrison and Job in favour of Doriva and Stuart Parnaby and switching to a 3-5-2 formation.

In contrast, Paolo Maldini - who was taken off at half-time after receiving a boot to the head - will lead Milan in his seventh European Champion Clubs' Cup final having most recently won the competition in 2003.

Lippi took off forwards Alberto Gilardino and Miccoli for Bernardo Corradi and Toni, but on 71 minutes Norway nearly pulled ahead again when Petter Rudi sent in a right-foot volley from close range only for Buffon to save well.
Pedersen was withdrawn for winger Dennis Rommedahl at the break, and the substitute added pace to the Danish attack, who had by far the better of the second half.
Sweden coasted through the second half, withdrawing Larsson and Arsenal FC's Fredrik Ljungberg and sitting deep waiting for any Icelandic mistakes to exploit.

United were forced to bring off Neville at half-time with a suspected virus, but his withdrawal only spurred on Ferguson's men and Wes Brown had an instant impact, skipping past two challenges before feeding Rooney whose shot was palmed wide.
With 12 minutes to go, Parlour conceded a free-kick on the edge of the area and Kollman stepped up to bend a left-footed shot beyond Schwarzer.
The pressure eventually told on Austria when Ernst Dospel conceded a penalty by handling the ball as Santiago Ezquerro brought it down in the box.
Crvena Zvezda were back in the game after 78 minutes when an innocuous-looking ball from Boško Jankovic wrong-footed Ivan Knez and Fernando Carreno and allowed Zigic to steal through and score.
Di Canio squared the ball to Muzzi and he struck a low outswinging shot through a crowd of Egaleo defenders and beyond a wrong-footed Srdan Kljajevic.

Play swung straight up the other end, John de Jong touching Cocu's left-wing cross just past the post, before Van Bommel came even closer on the stroke of half-time, flashing a half-volley wide with Chalkias wrong-footed after the goalkeeper had punched clear.
Wales spurned two good opportunities at the start of the second half, with Bellamy and Simon Davies both blasting over.
The home side had become the counterattacking team and a great chance was squandered by Poborský on 72 minutes.

FC Basel 1893 held on for a potentially crucial UEFA Cup Group A victory against Ferencvárosi TC, who missed a golden opportunity to earn a share of the spoils at the Ferenc Puskás stadium as goalkeeper Lajos Szücs missed an 85th-minute penalty.
However, after missing several chances in the opening 70 minutes of the game, Brugge may have felt slightly relieved to come away with such an emphatic victory.
Nedved then spurned an opportunity himself from close range as Juve finished the half in commanding fashion.
There was still time for Meijer to waste the easiest chance of the game to make it 3-0, mis-kicking from close range after more good work on the left from Michalke.
With half-time approaching, Cristea squandered a gilt-edged chance to give the Romanian side a half-time interval lead, taking too long to shoot when one-on-one with Reina.

Longford, despite their poor recent form domestically, started brightest but Sean Prunty spurned a promising opportunity when firing the ball across the face of goal after a combination of Eric Lavine and Vinny Perth had robbed Vaduz captain Martin Stocklasa in midfield.
The keeper saved bravely at the Frenchman's feet but Xavi Hernández, following up, sliced the ball over the gaping net.
Rosenborg battled back for a second time and on 76 minutes Helstad was again the hero for the home fans, following up a rebound after Chalkias had saved his initial header to score.
Juventus should have opened their account when left-back Gianluca Zambrotta delivered a cross to Ibrahimovic in front of goal but the towering Swede headed high over the crossbar.

Quaresma swung an inviting cross in from the right flank, but the former Tottenham Hotspur FC striker was unable to reproduce the header he scored against England for Portugal during UEFA EURO 2004™ and his attempt flew over the bar.
Midway through the half, Georgiou was again the instigator, threading a perfectly weighted pass to Ioannis Okkas, but the striker was twice denied by Fabien Barthez.

Slovenian Milenko Acimovic, an increasing influence in midfield, was fortunate to break free from two Zenit challenges on the edge of the area, but he did and played a weighted pass into the stride of captain Tafforeau, who arrowed a shot across the goalkeeper into the top corner.
Liedson played a perfectly weighted pass through to Tinga and from close-range the Brazilian was denied by an excellent stop with his feet by Jürgen Macho.
Kuijt chipped a sublime pass from the right to Kalou who scored with a diving header into the bottom corner of Rost’s net.
It was the same combination again as Akalé latched on to a long ball before advancing into the box and chipping a perfect cross to Pieroni, who headed beyond Malarz.

Patrick Vieira claims Wayne Rooney dived to win the penalty which helped Manchester United end Arsenal's 49-match unbeaten league run last season.
Dudelange goalkeeper Jonathan Joubert was called into action as early as the fifth minute after Virginius Liubšys' men had won a corner.
After Imants Bleidelis had given Latvia the lead, Verpakovskis won a penalty to allow Juris Laizans to score the second from the spot.
The deadlock was broken after 25 minutes when hard-working frontman Zizis Vryzas won a free-kick.

Austria won a free-kick on the right and there appeared no immediate danger but Štepán Vachoušek produced a stunning strike which curled past everybody and smacked on to the top of the post with keeper Luis García well beaten.

Yet the industrious Park was ever keen to stamp some quality on proceedings, first teasing Abidal and sending in an effort which hit Claudio Caçapa in the face before linking well with countryman Lee and bending a shot over Grégory Coupet's bar.

On 38 minutes the Azeri defence failed to deal with a long throw into the box and the ball fell to John Hartson who drilled a low shot at goal which Dimitry Kramarenko did well to block with his legs.
Govou cut in from the right and fed the ball to Wiltord, whose clever dummy allowed Essien to steady himself and unleash a ferocious shot into the bottom corner.
As the game progressed, the home side carved out the first real chance, Tuncay Sanli thundering a drive that had Jaromír Blazek acrobatically tipping the effort on to his crossbar.
He ran forward with the ball before unleashing a drive into the bottom right-hand corner to settle the contest.

Cocu sprang forward in the 79th minute and rifled a low shot into the bottom corner from the edge of the penalty area, scoring a potentially crucial away goal from virtually the visitors' first chance of the game.
A goal for either side now would clinch it: a Cissé header was held on the line by Cech, then Eidur Gudjohnsen arrowed a shot across the face of goal deep into added time.
With Semberas still making his way down the tunnel, Pauleta flashed a diving header just wide.

After Simão Sabrosa had missed a golden opportunity from Luisão's cross, Karadas, who appeared five minutes earlier as a 68th-minute substitute for Zahovic, ran on to a long ball and thundered a shot past Vanderbuussche to the jubilation of the home support.

Slovenian Milenko Acimovic, an increasing influence in midfield, was fortunate to break free from two Zenit challenges on the edge of the area, but he did and played a weighted pass into the stride of captain Tafforeau, who arrowed a shot across the goalkeeper into the top corner.

In the 82nd minute, Sparta made APOEL pay for that let-off, as Pacanda picked up a loose ball around 20 metres out and, moving the ball on to his left foot, curled a delightful shot past the helpless Morphis.
The Norwegian curled a free-kick from the right-hand edge of the penalty box through the Leverkusen wall and inside Butt's near post for his seventh goal of the season.
Partizan were nevertheless a different side in the second period and Tomic made amends for his miss when he rifled a close-range effort past goalkeeper Vladzimir Hayeu after a succession of rebounds.
Depor brought their faithful to their feet in the seventh minute when Sergio, in space 20 metres from goal, unleashed a ferocious strike that fizzed narrowly wide of Chris Kirkland's right-hand post.
Dragan Jelic fired a warning shot in the 51st minute but the chance went just wide.
However, between the two goals Schalke squandered a great chance of their own when a long ball found the Feyenoord defence sleeping and Hanke blasted a shot straight at goalkeeper Patrick Lodewijks.

Gerrard, who arrowed an earlier free-kick straight at Roma, burst into the box and saw the goalkeeper again equal to his low shot, but Monaco were playing with more confidence and Farnerud had his stinging drive well saved by Kirkland in the 70th minute.
In response, Petit dribbled through the visitors' defence and from inside the area, shot just wide of Daniel Zitka's left-hand post.
Andriy Voronin carried the ball down the left flank before finding Husev, who put his team ahead with a smooth and powerful shot.

Hungary were content to let Sweden have plenty of possession in the opening 15 minutes but the home side failed to capitalise, especially when Christian Wilhelmsson broke through the defence only to narrowly miss the target with his shot.

In the final minute of the half, Milos Krasic dribbled past two Parma defenders to set up Deividas Semberas but the Lithuanian could not apply the finish, badly scuffing his effort high over Bucci's goal.

Bayern continued to allow Juventus space to attack and defender Jonathan Zebina dribbled deep into opposition territory to provide Del Piero with a fine pass but the 29-year-old forward turned and shot weakly at goalkeeper Oliver Kahn's feet.
Two minutes later Gustavo Boccoli came close to doubling the score as he shrugged of a defender before breaking into the area.
Olympiacos came out positively after the restart and unsettled Monaco when Pantos broke free on the left side of the area, but Okkas could only direct the full-back's low cross straight at Roma.
After just four minutes, Ivica Olic carried the ball down the left and crossed perfectly for Love to head in.

On 18 minutes, PSV were stretched again when Chevantón broke free down the right and slipped a pass inside for Saviola who found Plašil, but the Czech midfield player hesitated long enough to allow André Ooijer to block his shot.
Undeterred, Olympiacos pushed forward and two minutes later Venetidis broke free on the left and turned in a ball to Rivaldo who fired narrowly wide.
Greece now have five points from four games - the same as Georgia who drew 2-2 at home to Denmark on Wednesday.
UEFA EURO 2004™ winners Greece had been shocked 2-1 in Albania while Turkey, semi-finalists at the last World Cup, were held 1-1 at home by Georgia.
The draw ensured both sides maintained their unbeaten record after three matches, and they are now level at the top of the group with France and the Republic of Ireland, who drew 0-0.
Georgia will take pride in a fine result as they twice cancelled out Jon Dahl Tomasson goals to hold Denmark in FIFA World Cup qualifying Group 2.
F.Y.R. Macedonia, who famously also drew away to England in the qualifying competition for UEFA EURO 2004™, did not drop their heads however, and on 70 minutes they were back on level terms.
Only four minutes had been played when Oliver Kahn punted three-quarters the length of the pitch.
Albania play Georgia and visit Denmark on the same dates.
CSKA welcome Porto on 24 November and Chelsea meet PSG on the same day, but the 2003/04 semi-finalists can already turn their minds to late February, when they begin their knockout bid.

Sparta now meet Hungarian side Ferencvárosi TC, who overcame KF Tirana on away goals, as they seek to emulate their 2003/04 performance, where they reached the first knockout round only to lose to holders AC Milan.
The Serbo-Montenegrin champions will now meet Dutch side PSV Eindhoven in the next round with a place in the competition's group stage the prize for the winner.
Estonia play Liechtenstein on the same day.
The sides meet again in Munich on 3 November and victory would take Juve through.
However, Partizan gained in strength and dominated the last half-hour.
Željeznicar dominated the champions of San Marino from the start and were three up in eleven minutes.

The game was goalless at half-time, but by the 62nd minute England were four ahead thanks to strikes from Joe Cole and Michael Owen, a Chris Baird own goal and a deflected Frank Lampard effort - just reward for a match the home side dominated against their near neighbours.

Central defender Anton Ehman went close with a near-post header from Kollman's free-kick on 21 minutes but the best chance of the half fell to Imants Bleidelis after Franck Queudrue and Gareth Southgate had challenged for the same ball.
Porto's Jorge Costa (left) challenges Ivica Olic
Shelbourne's David Crawley (left) tries to tackle Manuel Pablo of Deportivo
Teever was again involved, sending in a dangerous cross from the right, and when Zahovaiko challenged Manou Schauls in the penalty area, the Luxembourg defender directed the ball into his own goal.
Amica's Jaroslaw Bieniuk (left) challenges Jan Kromkamp
Gilewicz played the ball to Ivica Vastic who was tackled as he lined up a shot.
The Welsh international then burst past Mariusz Lewandowski and Anatoliy Tymoschuk before crossing for Henri Camara, but the Senegalese forward was tackled before he could shoot.
His hooked shot looked to be dropping in under the crossbar, but goalkeeper Borut Mavric tipped the ball over.
Zahovaiko stepped up to take the spot-kick himself only to see Pirih deny him with a fine save.
Benjani Mwaruwari had the home side's first effort but his curling shot was safely gathered by goalkeeper Andreas Schranz.

Milan Pacanda tested Coupet from long range, hitting a stinging shot that the French veteran gathered at the second attempt, and curly-haired midfielder Lukáš Zelenka also had a good chance to increase the Czech side's lead on 21 minutes, but shot over instead.
Newcastle became even more comfortable a quarter of an hour later when captain Shearer smashed a low free-kick which goalkeeper Brian Vanderbussche could only palm into the net.

Benayoun was tripped after dispossessing Costas Kaiafas on the edge of his own area and although Panagiotou managed to parry Nimni's powerful free-kick, the ball rolled to Adoram Keisi who finished coolly.
Salihamidzic then won a corner at the other end but the ensuing kick was punched away cleanly by Buffon.
Makris nearly gave the home team the lead moments later after Peruzzi spilled the ball, but could only scoop over.
A diagonal pass from Pirlo picked out Shevchenko but the Ukrainian's side-foot volley was gathered by Gomes.
On 18 minutes, the slightly-built captain lofted in a free-kick that Standard goalkeeper Vedran Runje almost punched into his own goal.
His looping header looked like it was floating in, but the German keeper managed to race back and catch the ball before it crossed the line.
Some nice interplay after 41 minutes concluded in a smart backheel from McCarthy to Diego, but his strike from outside the box was easily collected by PSG goalkeeper Lionel Letizi.
A low free-kick from a narrow angle on 50 minutes was spilled by Ricardo but steered wide by Ameobi.
Ronaldo burst into the box on three minutes and shot fiercely at goal, but Viacheslav Malafeev palmed his effort away.
But after the restart the game opened up again and Gordon saved from Dénes Rósa before Szücs, at full stretch, tipped away Stewart's low drive.
Huss almost found the right net with a fierce free-kick on the hour that Ricardo collected at the second attempt.
Torsten Frings shot on goal but his attempt lacked pace and was collected easily by Gianluigi Buffon.
Ishmael Addo then tried catching Stekelenburg off his line with an ambitious shot from the halfway line, but the tall Dutch keeper recovered in time to collect the ball with ease.

In his absence, Jonatan Johansson played as a lone striker and the Charlton Athletic FC man had the visitors' best opening of the first half, crashing a header against the bar after Bogdan Lobont had parried.
Moldova then settled down and on four minutes Yury Miterev headed on goal, but Vasily Khomutovski caught the ball.
Their best chance came from a curling free-kick that Alex powered over the United wall only to see Howard collect.
Hildebrand, who was Stuttgart's best player on the night, saved Simplicio's first effort but Pisanu then scored from the rebound.
On 21 minutes Andorra goalkeeper Koldo Alvarez was called into action as he stopped Aleksandar Vasoski's close-range shot following a scramble in the box.

Israel had Davidovitch to thank for keeping the scores level when his reflex save denied Vonlanthen from close range, and the home side almost scored when Patrick Müller sliced Afek's cross straight at Zuberbühler.
Van Der Sar was alert though as he stopped a header from Aleksandar Bajevski.
Porto gave themselves a lifeline in the 69th minute when a left-wing corner was fumbled by Toldo, allowing Jorge Costa to poke the ball in.
Gökdeniz Karadeniz further tested a tiring Albanian defence, but Elion Lika kept the deficit down when he stopped the substitute's close-range shot.
Kahn was then called upon twice in quick succession, saving Mauro Rosales's header and then punching Sneijder's free-kick away.
Goalkeeper Zurab Mamaladze elected to punch rather than catch the ball from a Robert corner, the clearing header did not ease the pressure and the alert Bellamy thundered in a volley.
However, he fumbled the ball and Fabio D'Elia was quick to capitalise, rolling the ball into an empty net.
Christian Manfredini made a run from the right before sending in a stinging low drive which was palmed into the path of oncoming striker Simone Inzaghi by goalkeeper José Manuel Reina.
Juninho's low free-kick was intended as a cross but when Howard failed to gather the ball cleanly Cris was on hand to force the ball over the line.
Dynamo's keeper was back in action moments later to tip a low Figo effort around the post.

France finally conceded a goal for the first time in qualifying with seven minutes to play when Badier ghosted in unmarked at the far post to head in and send the Ramat Gan stadium into a frenzy again.
At the other end, Oliver Kahn was largely untroubled, but almost conceded a goal on 23 minutes before having made a save.
To be able to bounce back after conceding two early goals in such an important match is no easy task.
His effort, which flashed over goalkeeper Ricardo's crossbar, was to prove the home side's best chance.
Cacau came close after a cut back from the marauding Lahm, but his miskicked effort went wide.

Lyon, however, who had been restricted to long-range efforts for most of the first half, were more than happy to rain on Ferguson's parade when Diarra unleashed a speculative effort from distance which squirmed out of Carroll's grasp, and the ball rolled into the net.
Aleksandar Railic tried an opportunist shot from near the centre circle on 42 minutes to to the delight of the small band of travelling supporters but the ball went just over.

Gilardino had Parma's best chance in the opening 45 minutes but his header flashed wide while Fernando Meira's shot hit the back of Matteo Contini in what was the home side's best opportunity a minute before half-time.

The Premiership club, missing injured defender Celestine Babayaro and his cup-tied colleague Jean-Alain Boumsong, were making their numerical advantage tell and it was no surprise when they regained the lead just after the half-hour when Robert's superb free-kick curled over the Olympiacos wall, giving Nikopolidis no chance.
Malouda, frequently roaming in from the left, was proving elusive for the Sparta defenders and moments later he set up Nilmar whose side-foot shot flashed wide of the post.
The Milan captain misjudged a Hartson flick-on allowing the ball to roll under his feet ten metres out, but the English forward was taken by surprise and failed to take advantage.
He found space outside the Wales area and produced a beautiful right-foot effort which curled into the top corner, leaving Jones helpless.
Sparta captain Karel Poborský, who won his 100th international cap last week, almost won the match in audacious style 13 minutes from time but his clever back-heel rolled just wide of the far post.

The two combined to good effect in the 14th minute when Covalciuc beat Daniele Bonera for pace down the Italian right and Rogaciov met the cross with a shot that just bobbled wide of Gianluigi Buffon's goal.

However, it was the Spanish side that opened the scoring in the fifth minute, José Mari arriving to meet Riquelme's corner with a delicate header that went through the legs of Steaua goalkeeper Vasili Khomutovski.
Four second-half goals, two each from Kaká and Hernán Crespo, were enough to see AC Milan through to the first knockout round as the Italians beat FC Shakhtar Donetsk 4-0 in their Group F encounter.
FC Shakhtar Donetsk defeated an injury-hit Celtic FC thanks to two goals from Matuzalem and one from Brandão to stay in third place in UEFA Champions League Group F.

Gorica may have won 5-0 at Danish champions FC København in the previous round but they managed just one shot on target all night and once in front through Ernesto Chevantón's 18th-minute opener, the only question was how many goals Monaco would win by.

Olympique Lyonnais sealed their place in the UEFA Champions League quarter-finals in style, thrashing Werder Bremen, with Sylvain Wiltord scoring a hat-trick to help his side wrap up an emphatic aggregate victory.

United remain two points behind Olympique Lyonnais in the group after the French champions beat Fenerbahçe SK, but Sparta, for whom Karel Poborský was dismissed three minutes from the end, can now only hope for a third-place finish.
PSG went into the game in wretched form, having won only one of their first nine games of the season and with one success in their last eight Champions League fixtures.

The UEFA EURO 2004™ contenders were ahead early through Maris Verpakovskis but Mario Frick's equaliser gave hope to Liechtenstein, who last month gained their first four World Cup points ever by holding Portugal and defeating Luxembourg.
Benfica fall to third on goal difference after NK Dinamo Zagreb, who they next play, thrashed Beveren 6-1 in the group's other match.
Cacau came close after a cut back from the marauding Lahm, but his miskicked effort went wide.
Within seconds Otelul's Viorel Tanase found Costel Mozacu, but his effort missed from 12 metres out.
Robben had the first chance for the visitors but after a solo run past two defenders his shot missed the target.
There was still time for Meijer to waste the easiest chance of the game to make it 3-0, mis-kicking from close range after more good work on the left from Michalke.

Haber saved from Waltner on 36 minutes after Huszti and Sándor Torghelle combined to set up the chance, but soon after Hungary were ahead when Torghelle headed down for Gera to beat the home goalkeeper with a neatly-placed drive.

Andorra, who lost 3-0 in Finland in their opening match on Saturday, had barely recovered when they fell further behind, this time Besiktas JK midfield player Daniel Pancu beating Koldo with a low shot in the fifth minute.
